perturbation.changed_text:
4.5
For the sake of clarity, and for the purpose of this Clause 4 and this Amendment, any of the receiving Party’s Affiliates shall not be considered as third party and shall be entitled to have access to any Confidential Information disclosed by the
disclosing Party in connection with this Amendment. Subcontractors of the Receiving Party, however, are considered third parties and must adhere to the conditions outlined in clause 4.1(i) and (ii) before being granted access to Confidential Information.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction within the confidentiality clause. Initially, subcontractors were explicitly excluded from being considered third parties, granting them automatic access to confidential information. The modified text now classifies subcontractors as third parties, subjecting them to the stricter conditions of clause 4.1(i) and (ii), which require signed acknowledgements and prior written approval for access to confidential information. This creates uncertainty regarding the level of access subcontractors have to confidential information and which set of rules applies to them.

perturbation.explanation: This change contradicts the amicable settlement period calculation. The original text states the amicable settlement period is calculated from the *date the committee has been created*, however, the modified text defines the settlement period to start from the *date of the Notice of Dispute*. This introduces ambiguity as to when the amicable settlement period actually begins, which directly impacts when arbitration can be initiated. This could lead to one party prematurely initiating arbitration, or the other party claiming the arbitration period hadn't been initiated properly.
